content.text: What are the three major types of employee benefits?
content.name: 3Ovd

content.text: The major types of benefits are those categories of benefits that are more commonly met in companies across countries. However, this view is focused on the different types of insurance and neglects other equally major benefits.
content.name: DWlU

content.text: Offering health insurance, or some kind of medical plan, is mandatory in many countries, and there’s often publicly available medical care sponsored by employers.
content.name: YcKD

content.text: Life insurance shows that the company cares not only about the employee but also about their family. If the employee dies, their family will get a sum to cover funeral and other related expenses, and their cost of living for a set period. Disability insurance may cover long-term and short-term disability or illness. For example, if an employee gets sick, they can receive payments for as long as their sickness lasts.
content.name: SmdB

content.text: Retirement benefits help employees feel more secure about their future after retirement. In the U.S. For example, a common benefit is the 401(k) in which both company and employee make defined contributions to the employee’s account on a regular basis. Employers may also contribute, in some cases by matching a certain percentage of employees’ contributions. At retirement, employees receive the balance in their account. The amount may be determined based on retirement age and tenure at the company.
content.name: Qc6r

content.text: In many countries, paid time off is mandated by law, like in the European Union (Austria, for example, has a legal minimum of 22 paid days for vacation and Finland has five weeks). Employers in countries like the U.S. may not be obliged to offer paid vacation leave, but those who do it voluntarily can get a competitive advantage in talent attraction and retention.
content.name: sYMA

content.text: For similar reasons, employers around the world may choose to extend law-mandated leave, such as giving extra days for sickness. In the U.S., 71% of all workers in the private sector had paid sick leave as a benefit, according to a 2018 report by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
content.name: mt4G

content.text: Other time-off benefits may include training days and sabbaticals, which are usually voluntary for employers but can have just as much impact on employee engagement.
